misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that dividing a floating-point number (double) by zero (`t == 0.0`) will result in a runtime exception or program crash, similar to integer division by zero in Java. Consequently, they use an explicit conditional check to prevent the operation and default the result to 0.0.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, division by 0.0 for floating-point types (`double`) does not throw an `ArithmeticException`. Instead, it results in standard IEEE 754 values like `Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY`, `Double.NEGATIVE_INFINITY`, or `Double.NaN`. The student incorrectly assumes the strict error handling of integer division applies to floating-point division.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: The program assigns an arbitrary value (0.0) to acceleration when time `t` is zero, instead of a mathematically defined infinite or undefined value (Infinity/NaN), masking the physically meaningful result due to a misplaced defensive programming technique.
